tie.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to fasten things together or hold them in a particular position using a piece of string, rope etc
tie.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: I tie my hair back when I’m jogging.
One of them tied her hands behind her back.
Tie this label to your suitcase.
They tied him to a tree and beat him up.
I kept all his letters tied together with a ribbon.
tie.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to fasten something around, over etc something else and tie the ends together
tie.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: He had only a towel tied around his waist.
She tied a scarf over her head.
tie.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to make a knot in a piece of string, rope etc, for example to fasten shoes or other clothes
tie.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: Can you tie your shoelaces by yourself?
She pulled the ribbon tightly and tied a bow.
tie.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: if a piece of clothing ties in a particular place, you fasten it there using a belt, bow etc
tie.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: This dress ties at the back.
tie.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: if two players, teams etc tie or are tied in a game or competition, they finish it with an equal number of points
tie.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: Woosnam and Lyle tied for fourth place on 264.
At the end of the season, we were tied with the Tigers.
tie.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: a long narrow piece of cloth tied in a knot around the neck, worn by men
tie.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: I wear a shirt and tie at work.
tie.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: a strong relationship between people, groups, or countries
tie.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: the importance of strong family ties
Japan’s strong economic ties with Taiwan
close ties between the two countries
tie.translation[1].definitions[2].defini: the result of a game, competition, or election when two or more people or teams get the same number of points, votes etc
tie.translation[1].definitions[2].exampl: The match ended in a tie.
tie.translation[1].definitions[3].defini: a piece of string, wire etc used to fasten or close something such as a bag
tie.translation[1].definitions[4].defini: one game, especially of football, that is part of a larger competition
tie.translation[1].definitions[4].exampl: England’s World Cup tie against Argentina
tie.translation[1].definitions[5].defini: something that means you must stay in one place, job etc or prevents you from being free to do what you want
tie.translation[1].definitions[5].exampl: If you enjoy travelling, young children can be a tie.
tie.translation[1].definitions[6].defini: a heavy piece of wood or metal supporting a railway track
tie.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 2: a strong relationship between people, groups, or countries
tie.translation[1].note_box[0].sections[: He had developed close ties with many Republican governors.
Family ties have been weakened by older people living apart from their children.
Strong personal ties connect her to the area.
He was a loner who failed to develop emotional ties with other people.
Japan and South Korea have close economic ties.
the establishment of diplomatic ties between the two countries
Besides marriage, other social ties drew people together.
The ties of friendship that unite the two countries.
The U.S. is committed to maintaining close ties with Europe.
Israel established full diplomatic ties with the Vatican in 1994.
He said that he planned to sever his ties with the club.
